source.name: City of Minneapolis Solid Waste & Recycling
source.notes: Based on official Minneapolis accepted recycling and organics lists. One-Sort recycling accepts only #1, #2, #5 plastics. Comprehensive organics program includes BPI-certified compostable products.

materials.name: Plastic bottles and jugs (#1/#2/#5)
notes: Only #1 (PET), #2 (HDPE), and #5 (PP) plastics accepted
One-Sort recycling — bi-weekly collection
Set out by 6 AM; move away by 7 AM next day
Max weight: 200 lbs (large cart), 150 lbs (medium cart)
commonMistakes: Don't include #3, #4, #6, or #7 plastics
Don't include foam or styrofoam bottles

materials.name: Plastic cups and containers (#1/#2/#5)
notes: Only #1, #2, #5 rigid plastic cups and containers accepted
Check resin code on bottom of container
commonMistakes: Don't include #3, #4, #6, or #7 plastics
Don't include black plastic containers
Don't include foam or styrofoam

materials.name: Aluminum cans
notes: Bi-weekly One-Sort collection
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with liquid still in them

materials.name: Steel / tin cans
notes: A magnet will stick to steel cans but not aluminum
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food still in them

materials.name: Mail and office paper
notes: Window envelopes are OK — no need to remove windows
commonMistakes: Don't include paper towels or tissues
Don't include napkins

materials.name: Magazines, catalogs, and newspapers
notes: Glossy paper and staples are fine
Inserts and ads can stay
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic bags

materials.name: Books (soft and hardcover)
instructions: Otherwise place in blue recycling cart
notes: Minneapolis accepts both soft and hard cover books in recycling
commonMistakes: Don't throw usable books in trash

materials.name: Paper bags
notes: Must be clean paper bags
commonMistakes: Don't include bags soiled with food
Don't include waxed paper bags

materials.name: Flattened cardboard
instructions: Flatten to maximum 3 feet × 3 feet pieces
notes: Max size 3'×3' for blue cart
Remove packing materials
commonMistakes: Don't leave boxes larger than 3'×3'
Don't include cardboard soaked with grease (compost it)

materials.name: Paperboard / thin cardboard
notes: Thin cardboard boxes accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include if heavily soiled (compost if food-soiled)

materials.name: Refrigerated food and beverage boxes
notes: Refrigerated food and beverage boxes specifically accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include with liquid still inside

materials.name: Aerosol cans (empty)
notes: Non-empty aerosols are hazardous
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if still pressurized
Don't puncture

materials.name: Aluminum foil (clean)
instructions: Ball up into a fist-sized ball
notes: Must be clean
commonMistakes: Don't recycle foil with food residue

materials.name: Aluminum trays
notes: Aluminum is infinitely recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include heavily soiled trays

materials.name: Food waste (all types)
instructions: Place all food scraps in green organics cart
Includes meat, fish, bones, dairy, eggs, and all other food
No bag needed, or use BPI-certified compostable bag
notes: Minneapolis green cart accepts ALL food waste including meat, bones, dairy
Collected weekly
commonMistakes: Don't put food in the trash if you have green cart service
Don't use regular plastic bags in the green cart

materials.name: Fruit and fruit scraps
notes: All fruit and scraps accepted
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash — compost it

materials.name: Vegetables and vegetable scraps
notes: All vegetables accepted
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash

materials.name: Meat, fish, and bones
instructions: Place in green organics cart — Minneapolis accepts all meat, fish, and bones
notes: Industrial composting handles meat and bones safely
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash if you have green cart
Don't worry about raw vs cooked — both accepted

materials.name: Dairy products and eggs
instructions: Food portion goes in green organics cart
Rinse and recycle the container separately
notes: All dairy and eggs accepted in organics
commonMistakes: Don't put food in trash — compost it
Recycle container separately

materials.name: Bread and grains
notes: All grain products accepted
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash

materials.name: Coffee grounds and filters
instructions: Coffee grounds and paper filters go in green organics cart
Tea bags: check for plastic mesh — paper tea bags go in green cart
notes: Minneapolis composting accepts coffee filters along with grounds
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash
Remove tea bags with plastic mesh — only paper/compostable accepted

materials.name: Food-soiled paper
instructions: Includes pizza boxes, napkins, paper towels, paper plates, paper egg cartons
notes: Minneapolis accepts food-soiled paper in composting — unlike some cities
Paper egg cartons go in organics
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling — soiled paper contaminates
Don't put in trash if compostable

materials.name: Pizza box
instructions: Place in green organics cart — even if greasy
Clean pizza boxes can also go in blue recycling cart
notes: Minneapolis composting accepts pizza boxes regardless of grease level
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy pizza boxes in recycling — compost them instead

materials.name: BPI-certified compostable products
notes: Minneapolis accepts BPI-certified compostable products in organics
Look for the BPI logo — not all items labeled 'compostable' qualify
commonMistakes: Don't assume 'biodegradable' means compostable
Must be BPI-certified to go in green cart

materials.name: Hair and nail clippings
notes: Minneapolis composting accepts hair and nail clippings
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Cotton balls
instructions: Place in green organics cart — if 100% cotton and uncontaminated
Avoid cotton balls with nail polish remover or chemicals
notes: Minneapolis accepts cotton balls in organics
commonMistakes: Don't include cotton with chemical residue

materials.name: Houseplant trimmings
instructions: Includes dead flowers and small plant trimmings
notes: Houseplant trimmings are distinct from yard waste (which has separate collection)
commonMistakes: Don't put large amounts of soil — mainly plant material

materials.name: Wooden items (small)
instructions: Small wooden items go in green organics cart
notes: Minneapolis composting accepts small wooden items
commonMistakes: Don't include painted or treated wood
Don't include large wood pieces — those are yard waste or trash

materials.name: Plastic bags and film
instructions: Do NOT place in blue recycling cart
Take clean dry bags to grocery store drop-off bins
notes: Minneapolis explicitly prohibits plastic bags and film in recycling
Bags tangle in sorting machinery
commonMistakes: Never bag recyclables in plastic bags
Don't put any film plastic in the blue cart

materials.name: Plastics #3, #4, #6, #7
notes: Minneapolis One-Sort only accepts #1, #2, and #5 plastics
Check the resin code number on the bottom of the item
commonMistakes: Don't put non-accepted plastics in the blue cart — they contaminate recycling

materials.name: Black plastic containers
notes: Sorting machines cannot detect black plastic — optical scanners can't read dark colors
commonMistakes: Don't put black plastic in the blue cart — even if marked #1, #2, or #5

materials.name: Styrofoam / polystyrene
instructions: Not accepted in recycling or organics
notes: Styrofoam is never compostable and not recyclable curbside in Minneapolis
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling cart
Don't put in the green organics cart

materials.name: Shredded paper
notes: Minneapolis specifically lists shredded paper as not accepted — too small for sorting
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling cart
Don't put in the green organics cart

materials.name: Paper cups (disposable)
notes: Minneapolis explicitly lists paper cups as not accepted in recycling — wax/plastic lining prevents it
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling cart
May be compostable if BPI-certified — check for BPI logo

materials.name: Paper plates
instructions: Food-soiled paper plates: green organics cart
notes: Minneapolis does not accept paper plates in recycling
Food-soiled ones can go in organics
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling cart

materials.name: Egg cartons
instructions: Paper egg cartons: green organics cart
Plastic egg cartons #1: blue recycling cart
notes: Paper egg cartons are specifically listed as accepted in Minneapolis organics
Foam egg cartons are not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put foam cartons in recycling
Paper egg cartons go in organics, not recycling

materials.name: Receipts
notes: Minneapolis specifically lists thermal receipts as not accepted — contains BPA
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling cart
Don't put in the green organics cart

materials.name: Squeeze tubes
notes: Minneapolis specifically lists squeeze tubes as not accepted
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling cart

materials.name: Bubble wrap
notes: Minneapolis specifically lists bubble wrap as not accepted in recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling cart

materials.name: Napkins and paper towels (clean)
instructions: Clean napkins/paper towels: regular trash (not accepted in recycling)
Food-soiled napkins/paper towels: green organics cart
notes: Minneapolis does not accept napkins or paper towels in recycling
Food-soiled ones go in organics
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling cart

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: Yard waste has SEPARATE collection — do NOT put in green organics cart
Use yard waste bags or bundle branches for separate yard waste pickup
notes: Minneapolis keeps yard waste separate from organics/food composting
Check minneapolismn.gov for yard waste collection schedule
commonMistakes: Don't put yard waste in the green organics cart
Don't put in the blue recycling cart

materials.name: Pet waste
instructions: Bag and place in regular trash
notes: Minneapolis specifically prohibits pet waste in green organics cart
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green organics cart
Don't flush cat litter

materials.name: Diapers
instructions: Bag and place in regular trash
notes: Minneapolis specifically lists diapers as not accepted in organics
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green organics cart

materials.name: Wipes
notes: Minneapolis specifically lists wipes as not accepted in organics
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green organics cart — even if labeled flushable

materials.name: Dryer lint
notes: Minneapolis specifically lists dryer lint as not accepted in organics — contains synthetic fibers
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green organics cart

materials.name: Wax / parchment paper
instructions: Place in regular trash unless BPI-certified compostable
notes: Minneapolis only accepts wax/parchment paper in organics if BPI-certified
commonMistakes: Don't assume it's compostable — must be BPI-certified

materials.name: Electronics / E-waste
instructions: Take to a Hennepin County drop-off facility or recycling event
Or take to Best Buy for free recycling
notes: Never put electronics in trash or recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in any curbside cart
Don't forget to wipe personal data

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Do NOT put in any curbside cart
Take to a Hennepin County drop-off facility
Tape terminals of lithium and 9V batteries
notes: Batteries can cause fires in garbage trucks and recycling
commonMistakes: Don't throw batteries in trash or recycling

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Take to a Hennepin County drop-off facility
Latex paint: can dry out with kitty litter then trash
Oil-based: must go to hazardous waste
notes: Check Hennepin County website for drop-off locations
commonMistakes: Don't pour paint down the drain
Don't put liquid paint in trash

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Take to a pharmacy drug take-back location
If no drop-off: mix with coffee grounds, seal, and trash
notes: Never flush medications
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications
Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Clothing / textiles
instructions: Donate to Goodwill, Salvation Army, or textile bins
Worn-out textiles still accepted at donation bins
notes: Don't put in any curbside cart
commonMistakes: Don't put clothing in the trash if donatable

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
notes: All colors of glass bottles and jars accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass — wrap and trash
Don't include ceramics, mirrors, or window glass

materials.name: Candy wrapper
notes: Multi-layer film packaging cannot be recycled
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling cart

materials.name: Chip bag / snack bag
notes: Metallized plastic cannot be recycled
commonMistakes: Don't put in the blue recycling cart

materials.name: CFL and fluorescent bulbs
instructions: Take to a Hennepin County drop-off or hardware store
notes: Home Depot and Lowe's accept CFL bulbs
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash or recycling
Don't break them

materials.name: LED and incandescent bulbs
instructions: Wrap and place in regular trash
notes: Not hazardous but not recyclable curbside
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with CFL bulbs which are hazardous

materials.name: Mirrors
notes: Metallic coating prevents glass recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling with regular glass

materials.name: Ceramics / pottery
notes: Ceramics contaminate glass recycling
commonMistakes: Don't mix with glass recyclables

materials.name: Propane tanks
instructions: Take to Hennepin County drop-off facility
Never put in any curbside cart
notes: Pressurized containers are fire risks
commonMistakes: Never puncture
Never put in trash

materials.name: Large / bulk items
instructions: Schedule a bulky item pickup through Minneapolis 311
Or take to a Hennepin County drop-off facility
notes: Minneapolis offers bulky item pickup by appointment
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling

materials.name: Appliances
instructions: Or take to a recycling facility
notes: Appliances contain recyclable metals
commonMistakes: Don't put in any curbside cart

materials.name: Makeup / cosmetics containers
instructions: Clean rigid #1/#2/#5 containers may go in blue cart
notes: Small items fall through sorting screens
commonMistakes: Don't put nail polish in regular trash

compost: ALL food waste — fruit, vegetables, meat, fish, bones, dairy, eggs
Food-soiled paper — pizza boxes, napkins, paper towels, paper plates, paper egg cartons
Small wooden items (popsicle sticks, chopsticks, toothpicks)

recycle: Napkins, paper towels, paper cups, paper plates
Egg cartons (paper ones go in organics)

tips: Minneapolis uses BLUE cart (One-Sort recycling, bi-weekly) and GREEN cart (organics, weekly)
Only plastics #1, #2, and #5 are accepted in recycling — check the resin code
Black plastic is NEVER accepted even if marked with an accepted resin code
Set out carts by 6 AM on collection day; move away by 7 AM the next day
Green cart organics accepts ALL food waste including meat, bones, dairy, and eggs
Food-soiled paper (pizza boxes, napkins, paper towels) goes in the GREEN organics cart
Paper cups are NOT accepted in recycling — unlike some cities
Yard waste has SEPARATE collection from organics — do not mix
BPI-certified compostable products are accepted in the green organics cart
Visit minneapolismn.gov for collection schedules and the recycling guide
